ls

ls_pop.h File Reference

Detailed Description

Defines a population of lsystem structures and some methods needed to work with them.

Author:
Farhan Ahammed (faha3615@mail.usyd.edu.au)

Definition in file ls_pop.h.

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include "ls.h"

Go to the source code of this file.

Function Documentation

void assignRandomValues ( ls_population *  pop  ) 

Initialises the population.

Goes through each coefficient structure and sets a random number to each coefficient.

Parameters:
pop The ls population to add random individuals to.

void createPopulation ( ls_population **  pop,
const int  numparents,
const int  num_rules,
const int  rule_size 
)

Allocates memory for a new ls_population structure.

The structure is returned in the ls_population pointer given as a parameter.

Parameters:
pop A pointer to an ls_population structure.
numparents The number of parents in the population.
num_rules The number of rules the specified lsystem structure will hold.
rule_size The length or each rule (initially).

void generateChildren ( ls_population *  pop  ) 

Generates children in the population.

NOTE: The population should be sorted before calling this function.

Parameters:
pop The ls population to generate children.

double getfitness ( ls_population *  pop,
int  i 
)

Returns the fitness of the specified L-System in the population (which is represented as an array).

Note: The array is sorted first before obtaining the fitness value.

Parameters:
pop An ls population.
i The position in the array of the ls whose fitness is wanted.
Returns:
The fitness of the ls in position i.

Mutates the children in the population.

Assumption: The children have already been generated.

void savelstofile ( ls_population *  pop,
int  i,
char *  filename,
char *  lsname,
char *  comments 
)

Saves the specified L-System in the population (which is represented as an array) to file.

Note: The array is sorted first before saving to file.

Parameters:
pop An ls population.
i The position in the array of the ls to save to file.
filename The name of the file to write to.
lsname The name to assign to the L-System.
comments Any additional comments to be added to the created files.
